content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: Before I will go into the details of the first quarter financial results, let me give you a short update on OMV's strategic progress. At the beginning of March, we reached a major milestone in the implementation of our Strategy 2030. OMV and ADNOC have signed a binding agreement to combine Borealis and Borouge along with the simultaneous acquisition of Nova Chemicals to form a new company Group International. This strategic partnership with ADNOC in polyolefins will bring clear benefits to OMV and our shareholders, positioning us as a significant player in this competitive market.

The new company will be the fourth largest polyolefin player globally, which will provide OMV with access to some of the largest, most attractive, and fastest-growing markets across the Americas, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. Additionally, this partnership will enhance our competitive edge, as approximately 70% of the production capacity will come from feedstock-advantaged regions, supplemented by a best-in-class specialties business. Following a EUR 1.6 billion cash injection into the new venture, OMV will hold a 36.9% stake in Borouge Group International, further solidifying our strategic foothold in the industry.

 recontextualized_answer: This strategic partnership with ADNOC in polyolefins will bring clear benefits to OMV and our shareholders. The new company formed through this collaboration will emerge as the fourth largest polyolefin player globally, positioning itself to tap into the largest, most attractive, and fastest-growing markets across the Americas, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia. Leveraging a highly competitive cost structure, approximately 70% of its production capacity will be situated in feedstock-advantaged regions, further strengthened by a best-in-class specialties business. After a significant EUR 1.6 billion cash injection, OMV will retain a 36.9% stake in Borouge Group International, which will operate with equal shareholdings and joint control alongside ADNOC. This new entity will act as a substantial platform for organic growth in polyolefins, bolstered by a solid pipeline of near-term projects and an EBITDA projected to exceed USD 7 billion, highlighting the forecasted tremendous growth potential through the cycle. Moreover, we anticipate substantial synergies that will enhance overall performance and profitability.

 recontextualized_answer: The significant cash injection of 1.6 billion into the new OMV will not only establish a 36.9% stake in Borouge Group International—sharing equal ownership and joint control with ADNOC—but will also harness substantial growth potential in the polyolefins sector. Borouge Group International is set to become a formidable platform for organic growth, bolstered by a solid pipeline of upcoming projects. As we project EBITDA to exceed USD 7 billion, we also foresee substantial synergies of approximately $500 million per annum on a run rate basis by 2030. These synergies will play a crucial role in creating immediate value for OMV, which benefits from free cash flow and clean CCS EPS accretion while maintaining its investment-grade credit rating and ensuring its leverage ratio remains well below 30%. This strategic positioning of the combined strengths of the three companies will enhance Borouge Group International's capacity to deliver attractive returns to shareholders, with a projected lower dividend net to OMV of around $1 billion a year, further reinforcing OMV's commitment to shareholder distributions.

 recontextualized_answer: As is customary, closing the transaction is subject to the relevant regulatory approvals, including merger control clearances in markets where the companies sell their products and foreign direct investment clearances in Austria, Canada, and the U.S. Until completion, Borealis and Borouge will continue to pay dividends according to their current schedules and commitments. In Romania, we have reached another major milestone by commencing drilling operations at the Neptun Deep project, located 160 kilometers offshore in the Black Sea. This expansive offshore gas project, the largest within the European Union, is progressing very well according to plan and remains within budget, with first gas expected to be achieved by 2027. Neptun Deep will contribute an estimated 70,000 barrels per day to our portfolio. Meanwhile, our partner OMV Petrom is also advancing exploration activities in the Black Sea at an offshore block, reinforcing our commitment to energy development in the region. In conjunction with these efforts, we have successfully launched an oil plant in Austria, capable of processing up to 16,000 tons of hard-to-recycle plastics annually, marking a significant milestone in the chemical industry after 15 years of pioneering research and development. This innovative ReOil technology not only complements mechanical recycling but also addresses the challenge of plastic waste, aiming to reintegrate it into the value chain and reduce CO2 emissions by up to 34% compared to conventional plastic production.

 recontextualized_answer: The ReOil technology, which has been successfully implemented at our oil plant in Austria with a processing capacity of up to 16,000 tons of hard-to-recycle plastics annually, is a crucial advancement in our efforts to complement mechanical recycling. This innovative process not only reintegrates previously unrecyclable plastic waste into the value chain but also significantly contributes to environmental sustainability. Specifically, the ReOil technology is expected to reduce CO2 emissions by up to 34% compared to plastic waste incineration, representing a pivotal step toward achieving our sustainability goals. Building on this momentum, we have secured an EUR 81 million grant from the European Union to support the next phase of our chemical recycling initiative, which includes an industrial-scale real plant with a processing capacity of up to 200,000 tonnes. Additionally, this morning, we commenced operations at our green hydrogen plant in Schwechat, boasting an annual capacity of up to 10 megawatts. The green hydrogen produced will be utilized to create more sustainable fuels and chemicals, such as sustainable aviation fuels and renewable resources, further enhancing our commitment to a circular economy.

Such initiatives not only contribute to our environmental objectives but also position us well as we move forward into the current fiscal year's performance evaluation.

 recontextualized_answer: In light of our recent advancements, including the securing of an EUR 81 million grant from the European Union to bolster our chemical recycling initiative, I would like to summarize the performance of our business segments in the first quarter of this year. This quarter's clean operating result for chemicals was nearly stable at EUR 126 million, showing resilience despite market fluctuations. Notably, in our European business, we experienced positive market effects amounting to EUR 57 million, primarily driven by rising olefin indicator margins, which reflect an upward trend in demand and pricing within the sector. This positive momentum is essential as we move forward with our initiatives, including the launch of our green hydrogen plant in Schwechat, which aims to enhance our production capabilities for sustainable fuels and chemicals.

content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: Let me now return to the performance of our business segments in the first quarter of this year. Compared to the first quarter of 2024, the clean operating result of chemicals was almost flat at EUR 126 million. In our European business, we recorded positive market effects of EUR 57 million attributable mostly to rising olefin indicator margins. However, inventory effects were positive yet EUR 11 million lower compared to the previous year. Notably, the utilization rate of our European crackers saw an improvement, increasing by 3 percentage points to 90%. Despite these gains, the contribution of Borealis, excluding joint ventures, declined to EUR 71 million. The base chemicals business faced considerable challenges, as the benefits of higher olefin indicator margins were more than offset by lower inventory valuation effects, a decreased like stock advantage, and higher customer discounts. Consequently, polyolefins also came in lower, primarily driven by rising fixed costs and diminishing realized margins.

 recontextualized_answer: The base chemicals business faced a considerable decline, as higher olefin indicator margins were overshadowed by lower inventory valuation effects, a decreased like stock advantage, and increased customer discounts. Consequently, polyolefins also fell short, largely driven by higher fixed costs and reduced realized margins. Despite these challenges, we managed to expand polyolefin sales volumes, excluding joint ventures, by 11%. This growth was primarily fueled by increased demand in the consumer products and infrastructure industries, although we observed a downturn in sales volumes within the mobility sector, aligning with overall market sentiment.

 recontextualized_answer: In the context of our recent financial performance, we were able to expand polyolefin sales volumes, excluding joint ventures, by 11%. This growth was driven by increased sales in the consumer products and infrastructure industries, where we successfully captured rising demand. Conversely, sales volumes in the mobility industry experienced a decline, reflecting prevailing market sentiment. Additionally, the contribution from our joint ventures rose to EUR 45 million, primarily attributed to improved performance from Borouge, especially following higher sales volumes. It's important to note that this contribution also reflects the exclusion of Baystar's results from the clean operating result, effective in March, which has been a notable change in our financial landscape. However, the benefits from Borouge’s growth were somewhat tempered by softer polyethylene prices observed in Asia.

 recontextualized_answer: The contribution from Baystar's result was excluded from the clean operating result effective March, which allowed for a clearer view of our performance. Meanwhile, the contribution from Borouge increased significantly, driven by higher sales volumes; however, this growth was somewhat tempered by softer polyethylene prices in Asia.  recontextualized_answer: Preceding the original chunk, Baystar's results reflected a clean operating performance effective from March, bolstered by increased contributions from Borouge due to higher sales volumes. However, this positive momentum was tempered by softer polyethylene prices in Asia. In this context, overall, the result was positively impacted by approximately EUR 40 million, attributed to the reclassification of Borealis as an asset held for sale following the transaction signed on March 3, which aimed to consolidate the shareholdings of Borealis and Borouge into Borouge Group International. 

Following this development, it is important to note that the clean CCS operating result for fuels and feedstock experienced a significant decline to EUR 117 million. This decline was mainly due to a lower refining indicator margin and a reduced contribution from ADNOC Refining and Global Trading, with the European refining indicator margin dropping by $4 per barrel, leading to a negative impact of EUR 110 million. Despite these challenges, the overall refining utilization rate improved compared to the first quarter of 2024, thanks to increased utilization rates at refineries.

 recontextualized_answer: The clean CCS operating result of fuels and feedstock experienced a significant decline to EUR 117 million, largely influenced by a diminishing refining indicator margin and a reduced contribution from ADNOC Refining and Global Trading. Specifically, the European refining indicator margin fell by $4 per barrel, leading to a negative impact of EUR 110 million on results. However, it is noteworthy that the overall refining utilization rate improved compared to the first quarter of 2024, driven by increased efficiency at the refineries. This improvement in utilization contrasts with the challenges faced by ADNOC Refining and Global Trading, which saw their contributions diminish significantly, approaching a breakeven result. This decline was primarily due to the weaker refining margin environment and reduced trading outcomes, albeit the marketing business, in contrast, reported better performance with increased contributions from fuel margins and sales volumes, alongside a robust non-fuel sector.

 recontextualized_answer: Building on the financial challenges faced in the CCS operating segment, the contribution of the marketing business saw an increase compared to the first quarter of 2024. This improvement was largely attributed to enhanced retail performance, fueled by higher fuel margins and increased sales volumes, alongside a stronger showing from the non-fuel business sector. In contrast, the commercial business's results remained relatively steady, mirroring the performance from the same quarter last year. However, the contribution from ADNOC Refining and global trading experienced a significant decline, nearing a breakeven result, primarily due to the ongoing weakness in refining margins and subdued trading outcomes. This trend came against the backdrop of the broader energy landscape, where the clean operating results of the Energy segment fell by EUR 142 million to EUR 910 million, as gains in Exploration and Production (E&P) could not offset the downturn in gas marketing and power contributions. Notably, the E&P sector benefitted from positive market effects amounting to around EUR 14 million, despite rising gas prices in contrast to a drop in oil prices compared to the previous quarter.

The contribution of ADNOC Refining and global trading decreased significantly close to a breakeven result, mainly due to a weaker refining margin environment and lower trading results.

question: What is OMV's current debt level and financial leverage position in 2025?

content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: The clean operating results of the Energy segment saw a decline of EUR 142 million, bringing the total to EUR 910 million. This decrease can be attributed to an inability of the improved exploration and production (E&P) results to offset the decline in gas marketing and power contributions. Notably, while the performance of E&P improved—driven by favorable market conditions resulting in around EUR 14 million gains—gas prices surged significantly compared to the first quarter of 2024, contrasting with a drop in oil prices. This setback in gas marketing and power was part of a broader trend, as production volumes across the board declined by 42,000 barrels per day, largely due to the divestment of Malaysian assets and natural declines in production from Norway and New Zealand. Despite increased output in other areas, this overall decline exerted further pressure on the clean operating results, which were also impacted by rising production costs, now at $10.1 per barrel, as well as reduced sales volumes that mirrored production losses.

 recontextualized_answer: The clean operating results of the Energy segment experienced a decline of EUR 142 million, totaling EUR 910 million, largely influenced by a combination of factors including production challenges and market dynamics. While the exploration and production (E&P) sector showed improved performance with a positive market effect of around EUR 14 million, it was overshadowed by a decline in gas marketing and power contributions. Specifically, production volumes fell by 42,000 barrels per day, primarily due to the divestment of Malaysian assets and the natural decline of production in Norway and New Zealand. This decline in production was only partially mitigated by increased output in the media sector. Accompanying this drop in production volumes, production costs slightly increased to $10.1 per barrel. Sales volumes mirrored the downturn in production and were further affected by the lifting schedule in Norway. The significant decline in gas marketing and power results worsened the situation, showing a sharp decrease of EUR 102 million, highlighting reductions observed in both eastern and western markets. 

Following this, the gas waste result amounted to EUR 120 million, largely propelled by lower storage results due to reduced summer spreads, but was somewhat balanced by an arbitration award of approximately EUR 50 million related to the Austrian supply contract. Overall, the situation reflects a broader impact from changing legislation affecting gas markets, with a notable downturn of EUR 104 million compared to the first quarter of 2024.

 recontextualized_answer: The results from gas marketing and power experienced a sharp decline of EUR 102 million, with reductions noted in both the eastern and western markets. This downturn was part of a broader trend reflecting the overall decrease in production volumes. Additionally, the gas waste result amounted to EUR 120 million, primarily driven by lower storage results due to diminished summer spreads. This decline was somewhat mitigated by an arbitration award of approximately EUR 50 million related to the Austrian supply contract. However, the financial performance in this sector was still notably negative, down by EUR 104 million compared to the first quarter of 2024. This significant decrease was largely attributed to the legislative changes impacting the gas and power sector in regions such as Romania, with the new regulations set to take effect in April 2024.

 recontextualized_answer: In the first quarter of 2024, the financial results for the gas and power sector experienced significant challenges, primarily driven by the change in legislation implemented in Romania, which took effect in April 2024. This legislative shift contributed to a decrease in overall sector performance, following a decline of EUR 102 million in gas marketing and power revenues, affecting both eastern and western operations. These reductions were compounded by lower storage results attributed to diminished summer spreads, leading to a substantial gas waste total of EUR 120 million. This context highlights the ongoing transformations affecting profitability in the energy sector while setting the stage for subsequent developments, such as the impressive cash flow figures reported later, which showed a rise in operating activities despite these legislative hurdles.

 recontextualized_answer: In the context of significant legislative changes impacting the gas and power sector in Romania, effective from April 2024, the company's financial results demonstrated notable resilience. The cash flow from operating activities was robust, standing at approximately EUR 1.4 billion, which represents a 32% increase compared to the previous quarter. However, this figure was 26% lower than the exceptionally high cash flow recorded in the first quarter of the previous year, a period that had been positively influenced by higher results and increased dividends from ADNOC Refining. The net working capital effects remained around neutral, indicating stability in operational management. Furthermore, the organic cash flow from investing activities was approximately EUR 1 billion, primarily allocated to ordinary ongoing business investments and substantial growth initiatives, including projects such as NextonDeep, the PDH plant in Belgium, and the sorting plant in Germany.

question: What is OMV's current debt level and financial leverage position in 2025?

content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: At around EUR 1.4 billion, cash flow from operating activities was strong, rising by 32% compared to the previous quarter, although it was still 26% below the impressive results of the first quarter of last year, which had benefitted from higher dividends and results from ADNOC Refining. Net working capital effects were around neutral. The organic cash flow from investing activities was approximately EUR 1 billion, largely stemming from ordinary ongoing business investments and key growth projects, including NextonDeep, the PDH plant in Belgium, and the sorting plant in Germany. Consequently, the organic free cash flow before dividends for the first quarter of 2025 amounted to EUR 441 million. Our balance sheet remained robust, with net debt stable and a low leverage ratio of 12%. By the end of March, OMV boasted a cash position of EUR 6.5 billion along with EUR 4.2 billion in undrawn committed credit facilities, setting a strong foundation amid anticipated market volatility driven by uncertainties surrounding ongoing tariff discussions and the peace process in Ukraine.

question: What is OMV's current debt level and financial leverage position in 2025?

content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: As a result of our ongoing business investments and major growth projects, such as NextonDeep, the PDH plant in Belgium, and the sorting plant in Germany, OMV reported an organic free cash flow before dividends for the first quarter of 2025 amounting to EUR 441 million. Our financial position remains robust, evidenced by a stable net debt and a low leverage ratio of 12%. By the end of March, we had a strong cash position of EUR 6.5 billion, along with EUR 4.2 billion in undrawn committed credit facilities. However, as we look ahead, we anticipate that market volatility will continue, largely due to the uncertainties surrounding the outcome of ongoing tariff discussions and the Ukraine peace talks. These factors significantly limit our visibility into future operations. While we do not expect to be directly affected by the import tariffs, as our operations are primarily focused on regional production and sales, the tariffs may still influence the broader global economic environment, thereby impacting OMV overall.

question: What is OMV's current debt level and financial leverage position in 2025?

 recontextualized_answer: As a result of uncertainties surrounding the outcome of ongoing tariff discussions and the Ukraine peace talks, our visibility into future performance remains significantly limited. While we do not expect to be directly impacted by the import tariffs, given that our operations are less export-oriented and we primarily produce and sell regionally, we recognize that these tariffs will influence the broader global economic environment. Consequently, this external economic context will inevitably have implications for OMV’s operations and strategic outlook. Looking ahead, as we adjust our projections for average commodity prices—specifically revising our expectations for the average Brent price for the full year 2025 from $75 to around $70 per barrel—it's essential to understand how these geopolitical factors may affect market dynamics and, ultimately, our financial performance.

question: What is OMV's current debt level and financial leverage position in 2025?

content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: Driven by uncertainties surrounding the outcome of ongoing tariff discussions and the Ukraine peace talks, which significantly limit our visibility, we have made adjustments to our financial forecasts. Specifically, we have revised our expectations for the average Brent price for the full year 2025 from $75 to around $70 per barrel. While our assumptions for European natural gas prices remain unchanged, we now anticipate that the average DRG price for the full year will trend closer to EUR 40 per megawatt. Despite not being directly impacted by import tariffs due to our primarily regional operations, the overall global economic environment influenced by these tariffs will still affect OMV's performance moving forward. As we navigate this uncertainty, it’s important to note that in the chemicals markets, we observed stronger olefin indicator margins in the first quarter, with further improvements in April. However, the potential impact of tariff implementation on the markets remains uncertain, and thus we are maintaining our full-year outlook for olefins and polyolefins as stated in February. We anticipate an increase in Borealis' polyolefin sales volumes, excluding joint ventures, aiming for around 4.1 million tonnes, which reflects a growth of 200,000 tonnes compared to 2024.

However, we now anticipate the average DRG price for the full year to trend closer to EUR 40 per megawatt.

question: What is OMV's current debt level and financial leverage position in 2025?

content:
title = omv_transcript_2025Q1

 recontextualized_answer: In the context of adjusted commodity price expectations and ongoing market dynamics, we observed stronger olefin indicator margins in the chemicals markets during the first quarter, with further increases noted in April. Despite these positive developments, the potential impact of tariff implementation on the markets introduces a level of uncertainty. Consequently, we are maintaining the full-year outlook for olefins and polyolefins as previously outlined in February. Specifically, we anticipate that polyolefin sales volumes for Borealis, excluding joint ventures, will grow to approximately 4.1 million tonnes—an increase of 200,000 tonnes compared to 2024. This growth occurs against a backdrop of volatility in the refining indicator margin, which peaked in February before beginning a downward trend, as we continue to project around $6 per barrel for the year, with all other full-year assumptions remaining unchanged.

 recontextualized_answer: In the context of the chemicals markets, where we have observed stronger olefin indicator margins and maintained our full-year outlook for olefins and polyolefins, the refining indicator margin has also shown significant fluctuations during the first quarter. It peaked in February before experiencing a downward trend, contributing to our expectation of approximately $6 per barrel for the entire year—an estimate that reflects our ongoing analysis, as all other full-year assumptions remain unchanged. As we look ahead to the first quarter of 2025, our projected organic CapEx is EUR 800 million, which is notably lower than the previous quarter, highlighting our focus on prudent financial management amidst market volatility. 

We remain highly disciplined in managing our expenditures, both operationally and concerning investments, with our full-year outlook for organic CapEx holding steady at EUR 3.6 billion, which is lower than the prior year. Our commitment to efficiency is steadfast, and we are targeting an additional cash flow of at least EUR 0.5 billion by 2027. Having already realized around EUR 180 million in savings last year, we are optimistic about achieving our 2027 target.

 recontextualized_answer: We remain highly disciplined in managing our expenditures, both operationally and in terms of investments, which is reflected in our unchanged full-year outlook for organic CapEx at EUR 3.6 billion, lower than the prior year. As highlighted in the recent trading update following the Borouge Group International deal, the reclassification of Borealis as an asset held for sale is expected to have a positive impact on our clean operating results, contributing around EUR 140 million per quarter. This reclassification, along with the exclusion of the associated results, reinforces our financial position without affecting cash flow.

Looking forward, we anticipate substantial dividend payments from Borouge, enhancing our overall financial stability. For the second quarter of this year alone, we are due to receive approximately EUR 220 million as the second installment for the 2024 dividend. Furthermore, Borouge has announced that total cash dividends for 2025 will be around $1.3 billion, with an initial tranche of about EUR 220 million net to OMV scheduled for payment in the fourth quarter of 2025, followed by a second installment in 2026.

 recontextualized_answer: In the first quarter, we observed significant market dynamics, particularly in the refining sector. While refinery margins were notably volatile, they have, in principle, remained stable enough to allow us to maintain our utilization rates. Currently, we are averaging refining margins above $6, which bodes well for our future operations. However, we also need to acknowledge shifts in the market mix. Specifically, there has been an increase in lower-end refinery products, leading to reduced margins. Additionally, middle distillates are still experiencing pressure, with the notable exceptions of sustainable aviation fuels and kerosene. At the same time, the chemicals sector presents potential growth opportunities, particularly with our petrochemical products, as exhibited by the recent recovery in olefin prices in April. This multifaceted landscape underscores both the challenges and opportunities we face moving forward.

So this will also give us opportunities for the future.

This positive trend suggests that while we face certain risks, such as fluctuating margins at the lower end of the refinery mix impacting our overall profitability, there are also viable market opportunities that we need to strategically navigate. Balancing these factors is crucial as we assess the evolving landscape, especially given the potential impacts of feedstock costs and regional price variations that have recently come into play. In contrast to the advantages seen in our Nordic crackers, which may experience slightly lower light feedstock benefits than last year, the North American market is poised to gain from falling oil prices. As gas prices have decreased at the start of the second quarter, the implications of these changes will require careful consideration moving forward.

 recontextualized_answer: Reinhard Florey

Yes. Thanks, Alejandro. I'll address your second question first and then hand over the first question for further elaboration. Concerning our balance sheet and the anticipated increase in leverage due to the Borouge transaction, we remain very confident in OMV's strong financial position. Importantly, we believe there is no need for us to divest any business assets, as we have already streamlined our portfolio effectively. Additionally, the extra leverage from the equity injection into BGI will be limited to approximately EUR 1.5 billion, which is well within our leverage target of 30%. We estimate that even with this increase, our leverage rate will rise only slightly above 20%. Therefore, at this time, we are not contemplating any major divestments, although periodic evaluations of our portfolio are a standard practice.

 recontextualized_answer: Reinhard Florey

In response to your second question regarding dividends, it's important to note that our current shareholding structure includes 75% from OMV and 25% from ADNOC, meaning ADNOC serves as the minority shareholder. This situation results in a particular negative cash impact on our balance sheet due to the fully consolidated goals when there is an outflow related to the 25% stake during dividend payouts. It's crucial to understand this within the broader framework, as we are also experiencing contrasting dynamics, particularly when we look at our positions in Borouge. While the dividends received from Borealis and the trading activities involving ADNOC result in a positive scenario for OMV, this necessitates adjustments to expected financial metrics. For instance, the anticipated equalization payment and capital injection into BGI, originally forecasted at EUR 1.6 billion, may be revised down to around EUR 1.5 billion after accounting for the dividends flowing from both Borealis and Borouge, illustrating how interconnected these aspects of our operations are.

This demonstrates not only our ability to adapt in times of crisis but also the inherent resilience of our company. Coupled with this, we also maintain a strong net working capital position, which acts as a buffer when oil prices and margins decline. This flexibility allows us to swiftly release capital and convert net working capital into cash, ensuring we have reserves available to fortify our balance sheet. Overall, these proactive strategies across our operations underscore our commitment to maintaining financial stability and responsiveness in a volatile market.

 recontextualized_answer: So you would see the operating cash flow and free cash flow both reflect EUR 900 million, demonstrating a solid performance. In the Chemicals sector, we are actively exploring opportunities to shift our portfolio towards higher grading, which historically has unlocked avenues for improved margins. However, in Q1, we experienced a decline in our share of the specialized chemicals market, which is something we are determined to reverse throughout the remainder of the year. 

Moreover, if we observe a certain recovery in the economy and a positive trend in the pricing of pre-materials and feedstock for chemicals, this could lead to a margin uplift that we aim to capitalize on in the market. This potential for recovery is not just optimistic; it aligns with our strategy to enhance margins and regain our competitive position in the specialties. 

Adding to this, the resilience of our integrated business model is crucial as we navigate these fluctuations. Despite the challenges, such as the weak refining margins particularly noted in Central Europe—especially in Austria and Germany—we remain confident that our model will provide the necessary support to weather these conditions while harnessing the opportunities that come our way.
